awd_titl_txt: Catalysis for sustainable aluminum-carbon bond formation
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Aaron Sadow of Iowa State University is studying the novel chemical reactivity of aluminum.  This research supports the economy of the United States since aluminum is widely available in North America and is of value in many industries including the beverage, housing, and transportation industries.  Of particular interest are the many useful aluminum compounds with bonds to carbon. Professor Sadow is developing new methods for making such aluminum-carbon bonds. The specific goal is to generate these bonds with newly designed catalysts that speed-up and guide the reactions to form desired products.  Aspects of the work are challenging because typical organoaluminum compounds decompose upon contact with air and water. In addition to this research project, Dr. Sadow is engaged in community outreach with the goal of educating broad audiences about the challenges and opportunities of topical issues, such as green chemistry.  The principal venue is community radio programming, which reaches both a local and national audience through a network of websites and archived shows. Professor Sadow also participates in an on-going seminar series on careers in chemistry, which introduces industrial and academic chemists and other scientists to undergraduate and graduate students.

In this project, Professor Aaron Sadow of Iowa State University is studying the catalytic reactions of carbon-hydrogen (C-H) bonds with aluminum compounds to efficiently synthesize alkynyl-, vinyl-, and aryl-aluminum compounds. Reactions of aluminum alkyls with alkynes and alkenes are unselective without a catalyst, giving mixtures resulting from metalation, carboalumination, and hydroalumination, depending on the unsaturated reactant and aluminum reagent. In addition, carboaluminum, rather than alumination, is the typical pathway catalyzed by early transition metals. Instead, Dr. Sadow is developing catalytic methods for alumination of alkynes involving substitution of a C-H bond for C-Al bond. The catalytic, salt-waste-free synthesis allows the new organoaluminum species to be used in two-step, one-pot reactions and takes advantage of the polarized nucleophilic character of alkynylaluminums. Dr. Sadow is also investigating the reaction mechanism through kinetics, for comparison with carboalumination. Dr. Sadow is developing a community radio program that broadly discusses the challenges and advances made by the chemistry community toward sustainable enterprises. Additionally, he is organizing a lecture series for Iowa State undergraduate students that highlights challenges and technical advances in green chemistry and sustainability in academic and industrial chemistry research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Scientific Impact. We have discovered and studied three new catalytic chemical transformations that replace toxic metals, utilize earth abundant metals, and introduce new functionality into organic molecules. The overall goal of the project was to develop sustainable chemistry for incorporating aluminum into organic molecules. Aluminum is the most abundant metal in the earth and is readily available and inexpensive, and alkylaluminums are heavily used in chemical industry.  In the first transformation, we use under-utilized and available lanthanum and related rare earth compounds to catalyze the substitution of a C-H bond in an alkyne with aluminum from trialkyl aluminum compounds. Previous to our new method, dialkyl alkynyl aluminum compounds had limited synthetic accessibility by catalytic routes because side reactions, carboalumination and hydroalumination, resulted in mixtures. We learned how catalyst design and reaction conditions could favor terminal metalation by studying catalyst structure with nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and by studying the reaction mechanism through kinetics.

A second investigation developed a scalable synthesis of 1,3-dienes from alkynes and ethylene. We developed a method that reduces the amount of Ru catalyst needed to make dienes containing functional groups, and increased the yields of the products, by controlling the concentrations of reactants and catalyst. We targeted functional group containing dienes because they could be used in co-polymerizations with butadiene to improve properties of polybutadienes, and conventional routes to functional dienes utilized undesirable reactants such as chloroprene.

We also developed a CuI-catalyzed conversion of furanoic acid into furan dicarboxylic acid, or benzoic acid into terephthalic acid. The latter reaction is known as the Henkel reaction and was originally used to produce terephthalate, an important monomer in polyethylene terephthalate (PET). The conventional Henkel reaction, however, used toxic cadmium iodide as the catalyst. We discovered that the first row metal copper, as its iodide salt, is a catalyst for this reaction and also the formation of furan dicarboxylic acid (FDCA) that can be used to produce polyethylene furanoate (PEF), a bio-based alternative to PET.

Broader Impacts. The above studies were chosen as based on the theme of sustainable catalytic transformations and have relevance in the context of using biorenewable feedstocks efficiently for manufacturing, or create routes to materials that improve efficiency in their use. Our efforts have also been to introduce all students into career opportunities in chemistry by connecting them with professional chemists, as well as scientists and engineers in chemistry-related disciplines, entrepreneurs and business people, agriculture and agribusiness, and medical professionals through seminars and discussion groups. We achieved our goals to inform students about possible career paths, inspire students to connect their budding interest in chemistry with future career prospects, help them develop networking skills, and guide the first roots of their career network.


Last Modified: 07/24/2024
Modified by: Aaron D Sadow
